title: Particle motion - total distance from velocity

content.question: A particle travels along a straight line with a velocity of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mfrac> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </msup> <mi>sin</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4780@</annotation> </semantics> </math> meters per second. What is the total distance, in meters, traveled by the particle during the time interval <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3BED@</annotation> </semantics> </math> seconds?

topic.text: 8.2: Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration Functions Using Integrals

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
